steps.content: â€œIt is what it isâ€ Thereâ€™s a dual meaning here. ğŸ‘ğŸ‘„ğŸ‘ is the kind of blank face you might make when things donâ€™t go your way and you have no choice but to roll with itâ€”it is what it is! steps.content: Weâ€™re not sure who used this combo first, but it became popular fast. One of the earliest tweets to use the emoji is from September 11, 2015. User @mily2502 tweeted some lyrics from the Backstreet Boys song â€œEverybody (Backstreetâ€™s Back)â€ and included the emoji combo as a jokey response to the lyrics â€œAm I original? / Am I the only one? / Am ah SEX-U-AAAAAALLL / â€‹â€‹ğŸ‘ğŸ‘„ğŸ‘.â€ [2] X Research source

steps.content: The ğŸ‘ğŸ‘„ğŸ‘ face quickly became a meme used in a variety of online jokes. A few years later in 2018, comedian Jaboukie Young-White (@jaboukie) used the emoji as a punchline in a joke tweet to comment on Americansâ€™ general lack or depth of history compared to other cultures: [3] X Research source â€œpeople in other countries: that church was nearly burnt down in 1315 by a queen who found her husband cheating / americans: wow ğŸ‘ğŸ‘„ğŸ‘ that mcdonalds has been there for 30 yearsâ€ Another viral tweet from @AnasApprentice3 shared an image of artist pencil boxes with pictures of eyes and lips on them arranged on a store shelf to resemble the emoji combo,

steps.content: By 2020, ğŸ‘ğŸ‘„ğŸ‘ was a common reaction to cringey videos on TikTok. The now-defunct website StayHipp described the emoji combo as an â€œindividual who witnessed the recording of a bizarre, funny, or cringey TikTok video and is staring in shock, disgust, or confusion.â€ [4] X Research source Sounds like a pretty apt description for such a versatile and abstract string of emojis!

steps.title: In 2020, techies hyped up an "appâ€ called â€œIt Is What It Isâ€ with ğŸ‘ğŸ‘„ğŸ‘.
steps.content: In 2020, techies hyped up an "appâ€ called â€œIt Is What It Isâ€ with ğŸ‘ğŸ‘„ğŸ‘. Some influential tech employees started adding ğŸ‘ğŸ‘„ğŸ‘ to their Twitter handles and even created an ominous, blank website featuring the emojis that only said â€œIt Is What It Is.â€ They never explained what â€œItâ€ was. An app? A website? Some new service? Like with other internet trends, a big sense of FOMO (fear of missing out) swept social media and users became fixated on figuring out what â€œItâ€ was. [5] X Research source â€œIt is what it isâ€ was also a popular meme at the time. It featured a video of a teenager laughing and saying â€œIt is what it isâ€ while his friends repeated the phrase around him. [6] X Research source

steps.title: The hype drew in thousands of wanna-be usersâ€”and venture capitalists.
steps.content: The hype drew in thousands of wanna-be usersâ€”and venture capitalists. Hoping to get in on the next big thing in tech, venture capitalists started offering the â€œIt Is What It Isâ€ group (which had about 60 members) millions. [7] X Research source At the same time, up to 50,000 people signed up for the appâ€™s â€œwaitlist,â€ hoping to be one of the first to experience the trendiest new social media experience. [8] X Research source â€œIt Is What It Isâ€ started collecting proof of donations to charities supporting the Black Lives Matter (BLM) movement to bump future users up higher on the â€œwaitlist.â€ The charities included organizations helping Black and trans people like the Loveland Foundation, The Okra Project, and The Innocence Project.

steps.title: Eventually, â€œIt Is What It Isâ€ announced that â€œItâ€ was a prank.
steps.content: Eventually, â€œIt Is What It Isâ€ announced that â€œItâ€ was a prank. After just a few days of hype, the team behind â€œIt Is What It Isâ€ announced there was no app coming. The entire thing had started as a joke among some friends and quickly became a large-scale trolling effort (with good intentions, as the team raised nearly $200,000 for charities). [9] X Research source Reactions to the prank were mixed: Some saw the stunt as a brilliant commentary on the popularity of memes and the â€œhype cultureâ€ in tech that pushes people toward the next new thingâ€”even if itâ€™s not real. Others thought the prank made light of the BLM movement and the struggle of Black people in America by reducing the movement to a meme.
